segments.text: We'll take two.
I don't really think the coffee would be better.
It makes me more nervous, and you might tranquilize me.
What sort of support did you receive, let's say, from your superiors when you began to consider the idea of consolidation?
In the early 60s, nobody saw any necessity for consolidation.
because they wouldn't see any necessity necessarily for oceanography.
We received complete support from, I'd say, the Secretariat of the Navy as opposed to the military side of the Navy.
And I think the reason for that is the military side was not that personally involved in the scientific side of oceanography.
And don't forget, we were just breaking into engineering in the early 60s.
Engineering really didn't even come of age until after the Thresher.
I think that's a relatively fair and accurate statement.
The Thresher forced engineering to come of age.
We had things before that, but it began to force the recognition of it.
As far as man in the sea is concerned, the Navy had led the world in diving, and yet the Navy got way behind it.
I mean, the people argue today that the Navy diver goes to 190 feet and the oil diver goes to 1,000 feet.
Well, the Navy did the science to get you to 1,000 feet, but the Navy won't operate it.
It's divers at 1,000 feet.
Because the Navy is a very conservative organization.
Its regulations are written in blood.
This leads you to believe that you have to be careful how you regulate things.
And I remember when they kept saying to the Navy, you take over the responsibility for certifying submersibles.
My answer to that was, all right, but always put that clause in there that allows you to exempt things for science and for research and for development.
Because if you insist upon the kinds of criteria that

bureaucracy will put on you, you'll never get from here to there because you'll always design something that's fail-safe, and you'll always design something based on what you had yesterday and not what you hope to get tomorrow.
So we always put that clause in the kinds of things we were doing and then ran it from the Secretary's office.
I think in today's world, the bigger bureaucrats, the head of the Office of Management and Budget and down a couple echelons, the White House,
And I speak of the White House in an amorphic sense and not whether it's a Republican or Democrat.

The Secretary of Defense, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of the Navy, and even the Chief of Naval Operations recognize that consolidation is a way, they look at it as a way of saving money and manpower.
I look at it as that's true, but I don't want to save anything.
I want to just get more so that I can do the job that I think we all have to do because we all know we don't have enough manpower resources or dollar resources.

And today I've had a lot of support from everybody in the bureaucratic system throughout government for consolidation for one reason or another, mostly because of the reason of saving money in billets.
And very little cooperation from most of the academic community and most of the scientific community because they see it as a threat to their existence or to their way of doing business.
And they have a rational fear
because large organizations tend to justify their existence on what they do internally as opposed to what someone else does for them externally.

And so we have tried to be very careful in the consolidation to ensure that the academic part of oceanography has a fence built around it so you can't use those dollars to build up somebody's empire internally.
I think that's a very valid fear.
That fear stated to me by the people I respect, like Tex and Calhoun and those people there.
I certainly, they've talked to me privately.
Art Maxwell, Nuremberg, Paul Fye, Walter Monk.
I can name you hundreds of people that have talked on that problem.
And I have had, they have been intelligent about it and focused on what the real problem is.
Many times,
People criticize you, and you spend an awful lot of time finding out what really is their concern, what is their problem as they see it.

Because it doesn't really matter if it's a real mathematical problem, because when you're dealing with people, a problem perceived is in fact a real problem, even though it's not a mathematical problem.
It's been difficult to sort out what people's real objection is.
There are very valid objections in the academic world.
I think we have pretty much
put the system in gear to ensure that the safety checks and balances are there.
In the other part of the world, that is the in-house internal Navy world, they're very concerned that you don't take away from them what they have.
I say they say what they need to do their job.

I would never take away from a man what he needs to do his job, but I would take away from a man what he thinks he needs to do his job when I think that the major job is yet to be done and can be done better in another group.

And I think there's another problem in today's world which wasn't necessarily here in the 60s, and that is that you're not going to get large amounts of money in either the scientific world or the Department of Defense world or the Department of the Navy world to build bricks and mortar.
We had that capability in the early 60s, both academically and militarily.
I think that that disappeared sometime during Vietnam.
And so as to the physical choice of where you do it, you get locked in cement in a hurry.
The reason they chose Mississippi was not the way the newspaper said.
There was no political pressure.
Senator Stennis didn't even know we'd chosen it until we told him.
It was a real simple thing.
About $200 million worth of bricks and mortar and not being used.
That's a phase out of the NASA project, right?
Yeah, it was built up for Apollo.
It wasn't started until 62.
By the time it was partially finished, Apollo funding was down to zero.
Not completely, but

It certainly didn't need a six-mile radius base of operations with a canal that connected it to the Gulf and a model base and a test and 48,000 feet of biology laboratory and 20,000 feet of computer space and all that kind of thing.
And I think that we gained from that.
And I think the taxpayer eventually gained because it means that the money they spent won't be wasted.
That's a way of saying it.
Of course, you can argue that.
It would be better sometimes to waste the taxpayers' money and stop something than to perpetuate it.
But is it not true that the equipment for NASA, for example, is easily converted to equipment for oceanography?
That place is probably 85% designed as you would design it as an oceanographer, frankly.
And that's an answer in saying yes to your question in more specific terms.
Have you found it easier, I take it now, to consolidate in 1976 than you did in 1963?
Yes, and there was one other thing that happened in 1975 that wasn't here in 63, and it began to happen right after the Vietnamese War.
The drive, and perhaps you'll again say that it's because of my parochialism, but let me put it this way.
The drive towards socialism in this country tends to dictate an increase in the bureaucracy in Vietnam
areas like health, education, and welfare.
So you know how partial I am, I'll say, in the giveaway programs.
By that, the whole country pretends they don't want to be socialistic, but they vote for programs which help themselves.
But they won't vote for just continually increasing the bureaucracy in Washington.
So this puts a pressure on the bureaucracy in Washington if they don't absolutely have to be here to get their A out of town.
So about 1970 or 71, a major drive was reinstated by certain members of Congress to get the Department of Defense and specifically the Navy out of the National Capital Region.
And this worked to the advantage of consolidation because if somebody is forcing you to get out, as you're leaving, you hopefully will head for one location instead of for 15.
And I think that was really the final straw that
that pushed us over the hump.
Sounds like an 18th century British idea of sending the armies out to the colonies so they can't be seen.
Probably true.
Probably true.
I think that's partially it, but from a congressional viewpoint, it's also so they can have more room to put in more of their own kind of troops.
In fact, it's fascinating.
Mr. Nixon, regardless of what you think of him, swore he'd decrease the bureaucracy in Washington.
He put out figures that said he'd decrease them by 1,000.
Mike Causey, who writes for The Washington Post, I think his figure was 11,000 increase.
And I trust Mike's figures more than I would the president's.
That's about what we increase to the year, about 10,000, 11,000.
All you do is walk around this town or fly over it, and you can see it's increasing.
It's Parkinson's third law.
It's just not the exception that proves the rule.
It's just Parkinson moving forward.
It's going to be that way forever.
I want to ask, the next question I want to ask you is one that you may choose not to answer.
And that is that between 63 and 75, 76, now you've been intimately associated with the development of oceanography now for 13 years and almost in a continuum.
Have you noticed any change in administrations?
Any congressmen who are particularly sympathetic towards you?
Any ones who are particularly opposed to you?
I can answer that question in my own view.
I think that
The congressmen who supported oceanography in the mid-60s maintained their support throughout their tenure in office.

I think the man we lost that was doing the most to bring things into focus was Alton Lennon of one of the Carolinas who headed the subcommittee on oceanography and who very fortunately was also on the Armed Services Committee so he could sucker the Navy into doing a lot.
He retired, and then there was a sort of a lack of leadership.
Mrs. Sullivan had the full committee, and she was leading, but she wasn't
able to devote as much time on just oceanography.
She was worrying about merchant marine and fishing and that sort of thing, but she wasn't able to put the time that Mr. Lennon put on oceanography in general.
And then we had the outer continental shelf problem that sort of masked what we were doing in oceanography and the law of the sea, which masked what we were doing.
And then on the House side, now we have a new leader there.
He's a very young man, Mr. Breaux from Louisiana, who I think is going to put the same drive back into the committee that Mr. Lennon had, or maybe more, because he's younger.
On the Senate side, we had Senator Magnuson, who I guess was the leader.
And he has certainly never given up a minute on his drive.
And he was joined recently, within the last, say, decade, by Senator Hollins, who has made a major effort in this area.
And there's many other senators and congressmen who have.
I don't think anybody has fought against it.
But I would say that oceanography has not increased for maybe two or three reasons.
is because of the apathy of the American public and therefore the members of Congress.

I remember Mr. Alexander from Arkansas coming over to me and saying, well, you know, they got cartoons of me sitting with a bunch of bikini-clad blondes and the beasts saying this is why I'm going scuba diving.

Well, the fact of the matter was he was up in very cold weather off of Massachusetts where there weren't any women around in the middle of the winter and the most horrible place in the world to go for diving.
But his opponents were trying to make it look like he was on a boondock.
There's another problem, I think, in oceanography, and that is nobody can really say what it is we want it for.
I can say what I want it for in the Navy.
Some of the oil companies can say what they want it for.
Some of the fishing people and some of the shipping people and some of the mining people argue about it, but they aren't as concrete about it as one would hope.
Then you have the dilemma of how much do you want the federal government involved in
in a subject.
Do you want it to regulate it?
Do you want it to control it?
Do you want it to do it?
See, I hold we don't want the federal government to do it.

We want to keep the federal government involvement from a bureaucratic viewpoint as low as possible, and yet we want to use the federal government's dollars to do those things which cannot be done on the outside for one reason or another.
And oceanography, a lot of that fits in that category.
On the other hand, we have developed, certainly within the federal government,
a significant amount of technology.
We are spending probably almost $100 million a year in academic oceanography today.
I think we should spend twice as much, but I'm not so sure the rest of the country would agree to that.
We're getting more than our fair share of the pie academically, in a sense.
It's spread further.
The rice bowl that started out with a dozen places
And you and I, knowing everybody that was in the dozen places, has now spread to several hundreds.

And the inflation being what it is, $100 million is only equal to about $50 million in 1962 in oceanography because of the high cost of ship operations and all this computer work and the salaries too.
So it's hard to say.
But I think that Mr. Eisenhower,
supported it not because he understood it, but because Mr. Wakeman came to him and said, Mr. President, here's what I'd like to do.
And Mr. President says, fine, Jim, do it.
But he never got any personal support from the White House beyond that.
Then the next president of the United States was Kennedy.
The way we got Kennedy interested in it was a lot of people aren't aware of this.
We made a movie.
It was called Science for Survival.
It was a catchy title.
It was done by the Navy.
But it wasn't done for the Navy.
It was done for oceanography.
And it showed the interagency committee functioning.
And we got Mr. Kennedy to agree to do the opening and closing to it.
And when we wrote the script for the president, he threw it down and talked in his own language.

And then the day that he was assassinated, I was sitting in the White House theater room or wherever it was we were screening the motion picture and had just gotten tentative approval from the White House to release the picture.
And Mr. Johnson made a...

arbitrary moratorium on mr. Kennedy's works for 90 days and I forget whether it was in honor of his death but that picture got caught in the moratorium then I had to go back and and say the ex-president you know and change the soundtrack has never got released then it finally got released mr. Johnson really involved himself in
My feeling was the following, and I'm sure that Senator Humphrey will tell you differently, and I'm sure Ed Wink will tell you differently.
My feeling was Mr. Johnson, being a Texan and being the man he was, felt very simply, hell, if you want to do anything in the ocean, tell the Navy to do it.
You know, he looks at life in a simplistic fashion.
I think the reason that he set up the President's Science Advisors Study, the PSAC study on oceanography, and I believe the title was Effective Use of the Sea,
was in response to congressional pressure.
It certainly wasn't on his own initiative.
I think it was in response to pressure put on by Magnuson and Lenin, they being the two leaders at the time.
You know, damn it, Mr. President, if you don't do something, we will.
No president wants to be told by Congress that they, Congress, are going to take the initiative.
And the simple way out of anything is to do a study.
So they did a study.
But, you know, we'd already done a NASCO study and a Navy study, and then we did a PSAC study.
Interesting enough, in that time frame, there were two things that allowed it to grow that do not exist today.
One, the Navy wanted everybody else in it and was willing to help fund it in a certain sense.
It's still willing, but it doesn't have the money now.
Two, there was so much to be done, there wasn't any competition among agencies in reality.
Three,
Nobody really realized what it was going to cost them, because they were talking science.
I guess there's probably a lot of other reasons, but those are probably the primary reasons.
I have heard people say in ONR that, as a matter of fact, the Navy went out deliberately to create oceanographic departments to handle, in effect, specific problems.
Well, more than that, we even, I remember one time, illegally,
operating the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries boats because they ran out of money and I needed to have something done.

And I think Tex was the guy that was in charge of the program to go ahead and get the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries fishing fleet, the government fishing fleet that belonged to the Bureau, out doing something for the Navy.
Certainly I had complete policy direction from the Secretary to do that because there was so much to be done.
I didn't mean you gold-plated or do it in a great fence, but it meant you were able to help them.
And, you know, sometimes I can't put the ship to sea, not because I need all the money, but I have to tie a ship up because I don't have the last $100,000.

Another thing we had then, too, which was very interesting, and that is I don't know how Mr. Wakelin accomplished it, but we had attention in then the Bureau of the Budget, which is now the Office of Management, and we had a man
at level three or four within the Bureau of the Budget who physically sat on the coordinating committees, and we did have some effect on other agencies' budgets.

And also, when the Navy ran the interagency committee, the Navy, in spite of what Ed Wink and other people say, had its staff under Bob Abel totally separate from the Navy, and they didn't work for the Navy except as billets, but they did not.
They were funded by the Navy, but they didn't take the Navy position, and they didn't know what the hell the Navy position was.
So they were truly an interagency group.
And we were criticized because the stationary they put out was put out as an interagency stationary.
But I think that was proper.
They were trying to do interagency work instead of Department of the Navy work.
When people start feuding with each other, it's very difficult to do anything together.
And you've probably read Ed Wink's book, Ocean Policy or the Politics of the Ocean.
He's an interesting individual.
I think made a lot of contributions
but I think was unwilling to use the Navy.
And I think in oceanography, whether you like it or not, you have to use the Navy because the Navy's there.
And I think you have to sucker the Navy into helping other people because there's certain things that no other agency could generate a critical mass to do it.
What other agency could generate a critical mass in the 60s to have built the navigational satellite system, to have built the submarine, to have...
computerized half the world.

Well, do you think there would have even have been an interest in, for example, oceanography developed in the academic world, or not such things as deep scattering layers, or bathya thermometers to measure thermoclines, or?
Maybe there would have been by the 1980s, 90s, or 2000, but certainly the Navy was the one that, as a result of his bad experience in World War II, in fact, drove the focus in oceanography.
But it was the Navy that forced still
the National Science Foundation into it.
It wasn't the National Science Foundation competing with ONR.
The Navy actually lobbied to get the foundation into oceanography because we benefit from what they're doing.
It was Dr. Wakelin, initially, who wanted the buoy system under the Coast Guard, who wanted the Sea Grant Program under the National Science Foundation and not under the Navy.
The earlier years were very cooperative.
The latter years, because of the forces of the dollar and so forth, have been perhaps less cooperative.
Although I would say, from where I sit, the academic community has been between 90% plus cooperative all the time.
They have their feuds among themselves, like we all do.
But I think that I certainly still feel that they're fully cooperative.
And I am not the major funder of the academic community anymore.
I've dropped from number one to number three, probably.
I take it that in terms of the move that you make to Gulfport, I think this will not separate you from cooperation with ONR and NSF.
No, because I will continue as a person to stay here myself and maintain the bureaucracy to fight for the dollars and to articulate the program and fight that in the joint arena.
But I think the technical workmanship coming out of the other elements of the program that were scattered around Washington
will be further away from the bureaucratic hot air that comes out of this town and therefore may be able to get together better with the academic community technically as opposed to bureaucratically.
I still will not put bureaucracy down in the technical activity, but I'm going to try to separate out technical accomplishment from bureaucratic hot air.
That's hard to do, and you know that, but it's just the way our system works.
I'm not being negative.
It's just that we are so big in this country that you just can't survive without a lot of bureaucracy.
seeing a lot of hot air.
Now, I want to go back to 63 again.

When you looked upon the problems you felt as if you had in the Naval Department of Oceanography, or the Oceanographic Department of the Navy, really, then how did you try to direct your department at once?
What were your immediate short-range goals?
Where did you think, in what ways should oceanography be?
Well, the first place we tried to move it was expand it in the academic community.

because if you look at the rationale for a subject which you understand very little, you ask yourself, well, since you can't foresee exactly what you're going to need and what you're going to have, like the game we were playing before, you say, all right, we need to pump more money into the basic part of it, and we are pleased with what we see with regard to the capability of the people that exist in the academic world, so why can't we get more people involved in the academic world and build up the academic program?
You do this simultaneously with trying to
Then answer yourself, what are your capital assets you need?
And the capital assets we needed or thought we needed were more ships, more modern ships.
We involved, parallel to that, a shipbuilding program for the academic world and for the Navy.

And thirdly, and I think not lastly, but I think almost just as important, was the sudden realization that the Thresher disaster should have awakened us to the fact that we may need to operate at any time at any depth because we didn't know what our competition was doing.
And I look at a military enemy as a competition, because you win when you've got a better product if you're commercial and you do the same thing in the military.
And a better product is people and training and equipment and knowledge.

And I think the Soviets have shown us how fast they could come from zero knowledge in the oceans to, and I'm speaking knowledge-wise, not military-wise, and how they're integrating their military operations in such a sense that the
knowledge of the ocean allows them to get an edge on occasion over us.

And I guess the scariest part was ocean engineering, because any one of us who's ever been in a major development program knows the difference between dollars for an academic scientific endeavor and an engineering endeavor.
And that's several orders of magnitude.
I think my knowledge with the Polaris program had already taught me just how costly

And I guess I have to retract the statement and say that my first time in oceanography really was with the Polaris program because then was a sudden realization that you couldn't get a missile launched from a platform under the water through the air surface interface without knowing, one, where it was, and two, how to go through this interface.
And I began to recognize for the first time how little we knew, how lacking we were even in such basic things as charts for submarines.

and also how little we knew on our accuracy of our navigation, because I'd grown through the same reform school and been told that the nautical almanac was accurate within 100 yards, and I was too proud to say when I took a star sight that I didn't know exactly where I was, and it wasn't until later in life I realized I was five miles off.
I got smarter as I got older.
But I think that was not age, that was just a... You'd been taught all your life that this is an accurate way to navigate, and it is mathematically, but
You add all the errors together of a rolling ship and a sextant and a mark one eyeball, and you get yourself a lot of errors, a lot of errors.
So I guess there was an involvement there, even if it wasn't an over-depriving interest.
So I take it then that towards ocean engineering is where you aimed the program right then, right?
I aimed it three ways.
I aimed it in the increased significantly, like an order of magnitude, the academic program in Rio.
And when I say an order of magnitude, I don't mean 10 times the dollars.
I mean 10 times the academic mandate's involvement.
In other words, how many people are working on research in the field?

And you've got to be careful here because we kept our money growing slowly, but in reality the number of mandates that we have today is half of what we had in the 60s, 10 years apart because of inflation and because of cost of ship outbreaks.
So I wanted to
go up several orders of magnitude in academic involvement.
I wanted to go up in capital investment on ships and computers.
I never won the business on computers.
The academic world started to do that, but the Navy world really never got to where I thought it should be.
And thirdly, and parallel to this, the real weakness in the Navy side of the program was real clear.
We just didn't have the technology to be able to see what the other guy is doing or go down on the bottom of the ocean or retrieve things or this sort of thing.
And that was costly, and that was really costly.
In fact, of course, we don't have that capability today.
Instead of the goal I set of six rescue vehicles, we have two, and neither of them are fully operational, and that was 10 years ago.
You know, it's frustrating when you stop and realize it.
Now, when you make overtures to the academic community, you try to extend your liaison to the academic community, did you try to meet academicians?
Oh, yeah.
That was in the beginning.
Well...
Working on the Interagency Committee with the National Academy of Sciences, I was actually either visiting their places or meeting them in Washington almost on a weekly basis.
And again, you've got to remember that these people were interested in the Navy's problems.
These people weren't just interested in the buck or the size of their university.
They were truly interested in some of the Navy's problems.
And I think this is a uniqueness in this field that was almost unparalleled, except perhaps during the war in the Manhattan Project.
But certainly, we had no problem with this.
In fact, even the anti-military feeling in Vietnam, even though it caused a few minor problems in certain universities, really didn't impact on oceanography.
Now, and so you make liaisons to the academic community, you have them work on specialized problems, and you also have them do work on generalized research as departments grow.
In terms of ocean engineering, then, did you try to tie that into the academic world also?
No.
At that time, I did not try to tie ocean engineering into the academic world.
except in one or two cases.

And that was a realization that certain tools that you could design, you could give to the academic community, and they could operate them for you in a better environment than, say, a military environment.
And the example of that, I guess the classic example of that, is the FLIP vehicle for Scripps and the Alvin for Woods Hole.
And I'm still working on that kind of philosophical approach.
And, of course, the MISAR for the Naval Research Lab, which the Naval Research Lab at that time in that particular group was very close, if you will, to an academic type of graduate training level.
I think that that's perhaps the best way to do it then.
Today, it'd be interesting to get the universities in the engineering field, but I wanted to make real concrete, specific improvements, like the physical capability of taking a man out of the
out of a submarine, or taking them off of a submersible, or going down on the ocean floor with a man.

Now, there's an interesting thing, because in the biomedical side of aspect, in the engineering side, because I sort of put man, the sea, and the engineering side of the Navy, we actually chose to do 80% of that work in universities.
Now, we're doing some of it in-house with the National Institute of Health and with the Naval NMRI, the Naval Medical Research Institute of Bethesda.

But, for example, the work being done at Penn and Duke and those kinds of places are significant and are making major contributions and have an advantage over the Navy that they can, they don't have to be as hidebound by blood-written regulations as we are.
They can perhaps go further in the forefront than we can, perhaps.
So that balance there was done intentionally.
But the rest of engineering, universities are not good places in general to build weapons systems or large systems.
They can probably do it.
And what I mean probably, they did it.
They built the album.
But they take a long time to do it.
